Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Short- versus Long-term Dual Antiplatelet Therapy for Stent-Assisted Coil Embolization of Cerebral Aneurysms

Background: The optimal duration of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) after stent-assisted coil embolization (SACE) for cerebral aneurysms is uncertain. This trial aimed to determine if long-term DAPT reduces ischemic stroke occurrence compared to short-term DAPT.

Methods: This multicenter, open-label, parallel-group randomised controlled trial was conducted in 17 hospitals in Japan. Patients aged â‰¥20 years, treated with SACE, and on DAPT were eligible. Exclusion criteria included recent ruptured aneurysm and high bleeding risk. Participants were randomised 1:1 to long-term (12 months) or short-term (3 months) DAPT with aspirin and clopidogrel. The primary outcome was time to ischemic stroke from 3 to 12 months post-SACE. Randomisation was web-based, with no blinding. The trial was registered (jRCTs051180141).

Results: From November 4, 2016, to January 7, 2019, 142 patients were randomised: 65 to long-term and 68 to short-term DAPT. Analysis included 65 in the long-term and 68 in the short-term group. Ischemic stroke occurred in 0 patients in the long-term group and 1 in the short-term group (0.0 vs 2.1/100 person-years; P=0.33). Two hemorrhagic events occurred in the long-term group.

Interpretation: No significant difference in ischemic stroke rates was found between long- and short-term DAPT. The trial was funded by Daiichi Sankyo Co., Ltd. Japan.
